title: Binomial Tree Up Factor
equation_latex: u = e \times xp \t \times im \times es (\t \times ex \times t{s \times ig \times ma} * s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (d \times el \times ta \times t))
notes: This equation calculates the up factor in a binomial tree. u represents the multiplicative factor for an up move

title: Binomial Tree Down Factor
equation_latex: d = 1 / u = e \times xp \t \times im \times es (-\t \times ex \times t{s \times ig \times ma} * s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (d \times el \times ta \times t))
notes: This equation calculates the down factor in a binomial tree. d represents the multiplicative factor for a down move

title: Binomial Tree Risk-Neutral Probability
equation_latex: p = (e \times xp \t \times im \times es (r * d \times el \times ta \times t) - d) / (u - d)
notes: This equation calculates the risk-neutral probability of an up move in a binomial tree. p represents the probability

title: Binomial Tree Option Price
equation_latex: O \times pt \times io \times n = e \times xp \t \times im \times es (-r * d \times el \times ta \times t) * (p * O \times pt \times io \times n_{u \times p} + (1 - p) * O \times pt \times io \times n_{d \times ow \times n})
notes: This equation calculates the option price at each node using backward induction. Option represents the discounted expected value under risk-neutral probabilities

title: Cox-Ross-Rubinstein Parameters
equation_latex: u = e \times xp \t \times im \times es (\t \times ex \times t{s \times ig \times ma} * s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (d \times el \times ta \times t))
notes: p = 0.5 * (exp(r * delta t) - d) / (u - d)

title: Jarrow-Rudd Parameters
equation_latex: u = e \times xp \t \times im \times es ((r - 0.5 * \t \times ex \times t{s \times ig \times ma}^{2}) * d \times el \times ta \times t + \t \times ex \times t{s \times ig \times ma} * s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (d \times el \times ta \times t))

title: Trinomial Tree Up Factor
equation_latex: u = e \times xp \t \times im \times es (l \times am \times bd \times a * \t \times ex \times t{s \times ig \times ma} * s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (d \times el \times ta \times t))
notes: This equation calculates the up factor in a trinomial tree. u represents the multiplicative factor for an up move

title: Trinomial Tree Down Factor

notes: This equation calculates the down factor in a trinomial tree. d represents the multiplicative factor for a down move. Trinomial trees have three branches (up

title: Trinomial Tree Middle Factor
notes: This equation defines the middle factor in a trinomial tree. m represents the multiplicative factor for no change in the underlying price. The middle branch allows for the possibility of no movement in the underlying asset

notes: p_d = 1 - p_u - p_m

title: Monte Carlo Option Price
equation_latex: O \times pt \times io \times n = e \times xp \t \times im \times es (-r * T) * (1/N) * s \times um_{i=1}^{N} P \times ay \times of \times f_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the option price using Monte Carlo simulation. Option represents the discounted average payoff

title: Monte Carlo Standard Error
equation_latex: S \times E = s \times ig \times ma_{p \times ay \times of \times f} / s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (N)
notes: This equation calculates the standard error of the Monte Carlo estimate. SE represents the standard error

title: Variance Reduction: Antithetic Variates
equation_latex: V \times ar \t \times im \times es ((X + X')/2) = 0.5 * (V \times ar \t \times im \times es (X) + V \times ar \t \times im \times es (X') + 2 * C \times ov \t \times im \times es (X
notes: Numerical Methods - Option Pricing Methods

title: Variance Reduction: Control Variates

title: Quasi-Monte Carlo
equation_latex: E \times rr \times or = O \t \times im \times es ((l \times og \times N)^{d} / N)
notes: This equation gives the convergence rate of quasi-Monte Carlo methods. The error decreases as O((log N)^d / N) instead of O(1/sqrt(N)) for standard Monte Carlo

title: Longstaff-Schwartz Algorithm
equation_latex: C \times on \times ti \times nu \times at \times io \times n V \times al \times ue = s \times um_{i=1}^{M} w_{i} * L_{i}(S_{t})
notes: This equation defines the continuation value in the Longstaff-Schwartz algorithm for American options. Continuation Value represents the expected value of continuing rather than exercising

title: Least Squares Monte Carlo
equation_latex: L \times SM = a \times rg \times mi \times n_{b} s \times um_{i=1}^{M} (D \times is \times co \times un \times te \times d P \times ay \times of \times f_{i} - s \times um_{j=1}^{K} b_{j} * L_{j}(S_{t_{i}}))^{2}
notes: This equation defines the least squares problem in LSM. LSM estimates the coefficients b_j to minimize the squared error between discounted payoffs and basis function values. LSM is the standard method for pricing American options with Monte Carlo.

title: Newton-Raphson Method
equation_latex: x_{n+1} = x_{n} - f \t \times im \times es (x_{n}) / f'(x_{n})
notes: This equation defines the Newton-Raphson method for root finding. x_{n+1} represents the next approximation

title: Bisection Method
notes: This equation defines the bisection method for root finding. x_{n+1} is the midpoint of the interval [a_n

title: Implied Volatility Newton-Raphson
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma_{n+1} = s \times ig \times ma_{n} - (C \t \times im \times es (s \times ig \times ma_{n}) - C_{m \times ar \times ke \times t}) / v \times eg \times a \t \times im \times es (s \times ig \times ma_{n})
notes: This equation calculates implied volatility using Newton-Raphson. sigma_{n+1} is the updated volatility

title: Brent's Method
equation_latex: C \times om \times bi \times ne \times s b \times is \times ec \times ti \times on
notes: and inverse quadratic interpolation

title: Gradient Descent
equation_latex: x_{n+1} = x_{n} - a \times lp \times ha * n \times ab \times la \times f \t \times im \times es (x_{n})
notes: This equation defines gradient descent for optimization. x_{n+1} represents the next iterate

title: Stochastic Gradient Descent
equation_latex: x_{n+1} = x_{n} - a \times lp \times ha_{n} * n \times ab \times la \times f_{i}(x_{n})
notes: This equation defines SGD for optimization with large datasets. x_{n+1} represents the next iterate

title: Levenberg-Marquardt Algorithm
equation_latex: (J^{T} * J + l \times am \times bd \times a * d \times ia \times g \t \times im \times es (J^{T} * J)) * d \times el \times ta = J^{T} * (y - f \t \times im \times es (x))
notes: This equation defines the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm for nonlinear least squares. J is the Jacobian

title: Calibration Objective Function
equation_latex: m \times in_{t \times he \times ta} s \times um_{i=1}^{N} w_{i} * (M \times od \times el \times Pr \times ic \times e_{i}(t \times he \times ta) - M \times ar \times ke \times t P \times ri \times ce_{i})^{2}
notes: This equation defines the calibration objective function. The goal is to find model parameters theta that minimize the weighted sum of squared errors between model prices and market prices. Calibration is essential for making models match market data.

title: Model Risk
equation_latex: M \times R = |M \times od \times el \times Pr \times ic \times e - M \times ar \times ke \times t P \times ri \times ce| / M \times ar \times ke \times t P \times ri \times ce
notes: This equation calculates model risk as the percentage error between model and market prices. MR represents the model risk

title: Backtesting
equation_latex: H \times it \times Ra \times ti \times o = (N \times um \times be \times r o \times f C \times or \times re \times ct \times Pr \times ed \times ic \times ti \times on \times s) / (T \times ot \times al \times Pr \times ed \times ic \times ti \times on \times s)
notes: This equation calculates the hit ratio for backtesting a model. Hit Ratio represents the proportion of correct predictions. Backtesting validates model performance on historical data and is essential for model validation.

title: Kupiec Test
equation_latex: L \times R = -2 * l \times n \t \times im \times es ((1 - a \times lp \times ha)^{N - x} * a \times lp \times ha^{x} / ((1 - p)^{N - x} * p^{x}))
notes: This equation defines the Kupiec test for VaR model validation. LR is the likelihood ratio statistic

title: Christoffersen Test
equation_latex: L \times R_{c \times c} = L \times R_{u \times c} + L \times R_{i \times nd}
notes: This equation defines the Christoffersen test for VaR model validation. LR_cc is the combined likelihood ratio

title: Bootstrap Method
equation_latex: t \times he \times ta* = f \t \times im \times es (X*) w \times he \times re \times X* i \times s a \times bo \times ot \times st \times ra \times p s \times am \times pl \times e
notes: This equation defines the bootstrap method for estimating confidence intervals. theta* is the statistic calculated from the bootstrap sample X*

title: Jackknife Method
equation_latex: t \times he \times ta_{j \times ac \times kk \times ni \times fe} = (1/N) * s \times um_{i=1}^{N} t \times he \times ta_{(-i)}
notes: This equation defines the jackknife method for bias and variance estimation. theta_jackknife is the jackknife estimate

title: Cross-Validation
equation_latex: C \times V = (1/K) * s \times um_{k=1}^{K} M \times SE_{k}
notes: This equation defines K-fold cross-validation. CV represents the cross-validation error

title: Regularization
equation_latex: L2 = l \times am \times bd \times a * ||t \times he \times ta||^{2}
notes: Numerical Methods - Optimization Techniques

title: Akaike Information Criterion
equation_latex: A \times IC = 2 \t \times im \times es \times k - 2 * l \times n \t \times im \times es (L)
notes: This equation defines the AIC for model selection. AIC represents the Akaike Information Criterion

title: Bayesian Information Criterion
equation_latex: B \times IC = k * l \times n \t \times im \times es (N) - 2 * l \times n \t \times im \times es (L)
notes: This equation defines the BIC for model selection. BIC represents the Bayesian Information Criterion

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
equation_latex: t \times he \times ta_{M \times LE} = a \times rg \times ma \times x_{t \times he \times ta} L \t \times im \times es (t \times he \times ta | X)
notes: This equation defines MLE. theta_MLE represents the parameter values that maximize the likelihood L(theta | X) given data X. MLE is a fundamental method for parameter estimation in statistical models.

title: Method of Moments
equation_latex: t \times he \times ta_{M \times M} s \times ol \times ve \times s E[X | t \times he \times ta] = s \times am \times pl \times e_{m \times ea \times n}(X)
notes: This equation defines the method of moments. theta_MM represents parameters that match theoretical moments to sample moments. Method of moments is simpler than MLE but less efficient for many models.

title: Expectation-Maximization
equation_latex: E-s \times te \times p: Q \t \times im \times es (t \times he \times ta | t \times he \times ta^{(t)}) = E[l \times og \times L \t \times im \times es (t \times he \times ta | X
notes: theta^{(t)}]

title: Kalman Filter
equation_latex: P \times re \times di \times ct: x_{t|t-1} = F * x_{t-1|t-1}
notes: Numerical Methods - Optimization Techniques

title: Particle Filter
equation_latex: w \times ei \times gh \times ts_{i} p \times ro \times po \times rt \times io \times na \times l t \times o l \times ik \times el \times ih \times oo \times d \t \times im \times es (y_{t} | x_{t}^{(i)})

title: Greeks by Finite Differences
equation_latex: \t \times ex \times t{D \times el \times ta} = (f \t \times im \times es (S + d \times el \times ta \times S) - f \t \times im \times es (S - d \times el \times ta \times S)) / (2 * d \times el \times ta \times S)
notes: This equation calculates Delta using central finite differences. Delta represents the sensitivity of the option price to the underlying price. Finite differences are used when analytical Greeks are not available. Central differences are more accurate than forward/backward differences.

title: Gamma by Finite Differences

notes: This equation calculates Gamma using finite differences. Gamma represents the second derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. Finite difference Gamma requires three option price evaluations.

title: Operator Splitting
equation_latex: S \times pl \times it \times PD \times E i \times nt \times o s \times im \times pl \times er \times su \times b-p \times ro \times bl \times em \times s
